I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Bhutan requested capacity development technical assistance (TA) 
from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  support  conducting  the  Third  Bhutan  Living 
Standards Survey (BLSS), a major source of data for assessing its five-year plan, 2008–2013,1 
assessing poverty, and updating weightings for the consumer price index. The most recent 
BLSS  was  conducted  in  2007  under  the  sponsorship  of  the  United  Nations  Development 
Programme (UNDP), following the first BLSS conducted in 2003 with funding from ADB through 
its TA for Strengthening the National Statistical System.2 The 2003 BLSS provided Bhutan with 
its  first  estimates  of  poverty  in  urban  areas,  rural  areas,  and  nationally.  The  2007  BLSS 
rendered good estimates at the district level and was the source of benchmark values for three 
sets  of  indicators  for  the  2008–2013  government  development  plan:  (i)  food  security  for 
vulnerable households in intervention areas, (ii) household income, and (iii) consumption of 
basic commodities. 
 
2.  The fact-finding mission on 14–18 February 2011 consulted with the government and 
major stakeholders on the issues pertaining to the BLSS and its impact, outcome, outputs, and 
implementation arrangements. The mission held extensive discussions with the government 
agencies that are the major users of the BLSS—the National Statistics Bureau (NSB), Gross 
National Happiness Commission, Ministry of Labour and Human Resources, and Ministry of 
Agriculture and Forests—as well as with the UNDP as the sponsor of the 2007 BLSS and the 
World Food Programme, both as users and supporters of the 2007 BLSS. These agencies 
contributed to TA design. In particular, the Gross National Happiness Commission underscored 
the need for the third BLSS to provide updated indicators for the government’s 2008–2013 plan. 
The mission also consulted with the ADB team on the ongoing country diagnostic study. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Another BLSS is needed to assess the outputs of the 2008–2013 government plan, 
which was formulated on the basis of the 2007 BLSS. The BLSS has data on household 
demographics, household assets and remittances, education, employment, health, commodity 
prices, and consumption expenditures, which are inputs for compiling the national accounts of 
the  household  sector. It  is  a good source  of data for  policy  research  and  updating  other 
economic indicators such as the consumer price index. The survey will provide updated poverty 
estimates  at  the  district  level  and  assess  the  effectiveness  of  implemented  policies  and 
programs designed to improve people’s lives. 
 
                                                
1  Government  of  Bhutan,  Gross  National  Happiness  Commission.  2009.    Tenth  Five-Year  Plan, 2008–2013. 
Thimphu. 
2  ADB. 2001.  Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan for Strengthening the National Statistical System. 
Manila (TA 3669-BHU). The TA supported the (i) provision of technical advice for drafting the statistics act; (ii) 
improvement  of  national  accounts;  (iii)  design,  implementation,  and  analysis  of  a  household  income  and 
expenditure survey; (iv) improvement of labor statistics collection and dissemination; and (v) upgrading of skills in 
the National Statistics Bureau (then the Central Statistical Organization). 
3  The TA first appeared in the ADB’s website project information document on 8 July 2011 and in the business 
opportunities section on 19 August 2011.

2   
4.  As the main agency coordinating statistics in Bhutan, and through a government order in 
October  2003,  the  NSB  is  mandated  to  be  the  data  collection  arm  of  the  government, 
responsible  for  updating  its  official  statistics.  The  NSB  is  expected  to  conduct  national 
household surveys, including the BLSS. However, although an executive order of the Prime 
Minister on 26 May 2006 reaffirmed the NSB’s function as the central authority for the collection, 
release, and custodianship of official data, other ministries have continued to collect data for 
their respective statistical needs. While many of these agencies expect stronger support from 
the NSB in the form of technical advice on survey methods, staff training, and disseminating 
survey  results,  the  NSB’s  coordination  of  data  collection  has  been  limited  to  reviewing 
questionnaires and selecting samples for surveys. Lacking budgetary support, the NSB relies on 
survey data that other ministries collect for updating many official statistics. Meanwhile, the 
capacity of staff of other government agencies to conduct surveys continues to grow, as some 
of  them  have  regular  budgets  for  conducting  surveys.  For  example,  the  Department  of 
Employment  under  the  Ministry  of  Labour  and  Human  Resources  conducts,  solely  with 
government funding, annual surveys on the labor force and business establishments, the two 
major sources of data for updating national statistics. 
 
5.  Through  a  World  Bank  Trust  Fund  for  Capacity  Building,  the  NSB  developed  a 
comprehensive national statistics development strategy in 2009 that provided a framework and 
action plan for building the capacity of Bhutan’s statistical system to meet current and future 
data  needs.  There  are  delays,  however,  in  funding  and  implementing  its  major  activities. 
Meanwhile, the NSB still relies on development partners to fund important surveys such as the 
2010 Bhutan Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey, which was sponsored by the United Nations 
Children’s Fund. Even if the BLSS is considered one of the most important surveys that the 
NSB has conducted, the NSB has to look for funding support and technical advice from the 
international  development  community  for  the  third  round.  This  is  for  lack  of  (i)  adequate 
numbers of technical staff for survey design and operation or (ii) a regular budget for data 
collection. The draft Statistics Act, which is part of the national statistics development strategy, 
would have brought about the upgrading of NSB status and provided the imprimatur and budget 
necessary  for  important  NSB  activities  such  as  the  development  and  regular,  systematic 
conduct of household and enterprise surveys needed to improve the quality and timeliness of 
official  statistics.  However,  the  draft  Statistics  Act,  targeted  for  completion  in  2009  and 
supported by ADB’s TA for Strengthening the National Statistical System (Phase 2), has yet to 
be promulgated.4 
 
6.  The BLSS cannot be postponed until appropriate government support mechanisms are 
in place. Apart from being a major data source for assessing the current 5-year plan, BLSS data 
supports multidimensional poverty assessment and can help stakeholders in the government 
plan formulate better development perspectives. Further, the proposed assistance can advance 
the promulgation of the draft Statistics Act, upgrade the technical skills of NSB staff, and 
develop an affordable sample survey strategy that will help ensure the sustainability of future 
BLSS rounds. 
 
 
                                                
4  ADB. 2004.  Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan for Strengthening the National Statistical System 
Phase 2. Manila (TA 4424-BHU) covered (i) the provision of technical support and equipment to the NSB and the 
Statistical Board, including the finalization of the statistics act; (ii) the improvement of national accounts; and (iii) 
apprenticeship programs for NSB staff.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The  intended  impact  of  the  TA  is  more  evidence-based  policy  making  for  poverty 
reduction. The expected outcome is the regular conduct of the BLSS with government support. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will consist of three major activities: (i) developing the survey strategy; (ii) 
training NSB technical staff, enumerators, and supervisors; and (iii) conducting, processing, and 
analyzing the third BLSS. It is essential that the survey strategy not only generate reliable 
statistics but should also be cost-effective, enabling the government to support future rounds 
instead of relying on external funding. The survey strategy should address major stakeholders’ 
requirements to inform policy and provide good data support to the government’s current 5-year 
plan,  2008–2013.  In  developing  the  strategy,  consultations  with  major  stakeholders  in  the 
government, private sector, academia, and the development community will be organized to 
assess stakeholders’ requirements and promote the use of the BLSS. 
 
9.  Recognizing  that  other  government  departments  may  have  already  mastered  good 
practices from regularly conducting surveys, representatives from the ministries of (i) agriculture 
and forests, (ii) education, (iii) health, (iv) and labor and human resources, as well as the Gross 
National Happiness Commission, will be invited to participate in a advisory committee that will 
advise  the  NSB  on  the  survey  questionnaire  and  operations  plan,  data  analysis,  and  the 
dissemination of the survey report. The work with the advisory committee can serve as a 
starting point for the NSB’s enhancing its coordination of data collection. 
 
10.  The methods of previous rounds of the BLSS will be analyzed, and the design of other 
countries’ household surveys with viable sampling will be carefully studied to plan sample 
selection for the 2011 BLSS and succeeding rounds. The possibility of assessing the impact of 
ADB projects in Bhutan using the 2007 and 2011 BLSS will be explored and, if deemed possible, 
the sampling design and survey operations will be planned accordingly. The development of all 
survey instruments—questionnaire, survey operations plans including manuals, and sampling 
design—will be documented for future rounds of the BLSS. 
 
11.  The skills of NSB technical staff will be upgraded through on-the-job training and a 
formal training program on survey methods that will be offered by the TA team during review 
missions.5 Survey  operations  will  be  planned  to  ensure  the  correct  implementation  of  the 
sampling  design,  optimal  use  of  available  resources,  and  control  of  non-sampling  errors. 
Moreover, NSB technical staff will train enumerators and supervisors to minimize measurement 
errors. 
 
12.  To further ensure skills upgrading in the NSB technical team, 2011 BLSS data will be 
processed, validated, and analyzed by the NSB technical team in close coordination with the 
international consultant and the TA team. Analysis results will be presented in the survey report, 
which will be widely disseminated through workshops and on the NSB and ADB websites. The 
public  utility  file  of  the  2011  BLSS  will  be  compiled  for  policy  research  purposes.  The

expected to raise public awareness of the importance of statistics for better policy making and, 
consequently, provide momentum toward promulgating the draft Statistics Act. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The cost of the TA is estimated to be $300,000. The government has requested ADB to 
finance $300,000 to cover the costs of planning and conducting the survey, analyzing the 
results, and writing the report on the 2011 BLSS; of international consultant services; and of the 
dissemination  workshop.  The  TA  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will provide counterpart support in the 
form  of  office  accommodation  and  counterpart  staff remuneration  and  per  diem. The  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The NSB will be the executing agency for the TA. It will organize consultations with 
stakeholders, convene the advisory committee, and form the technical team that will work 
closely with the TA team and international consultant to develop survey instruments, analyze 
the results, and write the survey report. The TA will be implemented over 14 months from 
October 2011 to December 2012. 
 
15.  The TA will finance 1 person-month of international consulting services. ADB will engage 
an individual consultant in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The terms of reference for the consultant are in Appendix 3. 
 
16.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The procurement of 
equipment, if any, will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time). Any equipment will be handed over to the NSB upon TA completion. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for the Third Bhutan Living Standards Survey, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANT 
 
A.  International Consultant: Statistician (1 person-month, individual) 
1.  The international consultant should have a strong background in statistics, extensive 
prior working experience with household survey data (including detailed knowledge of sampling 
survey and questionnaire design), and sufficient practical knowledge on living standards and 
poverty assessment. 
 
2.  The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Work with the technical assistance team leader and National Statistics Bureau 
(NSB) staff counterparts to develop a cost-effective and reliable sample survey 
design for the Third Bhutan Living Standards Survey (BLSS). 
(ii)  Explore  the  possibility  of  assessing  the  impact  of  Asian  Development  Bank 
projects in Bhutan using the second BLSS in 2007 and the third BLSS and, if 
deemed  possible,  provide  advice  on  how  the  sampling  design  and  survey 
operations will be planned accordingly. 
(iii)  Assist the NSB in developing a framework for analyzing the third BLSS. 
(iv)  Review the survey report that will be written by NSB. 
(v)  Participate in training and dissemination workshops on the third BLSS.
